page.title: 07JOHN ELLMAN OF GLYNDE
page.content: We saw the tomb of{John Ellman}in the churchyard. During the great farming improvements beginning 200 years ago, he made Glynde famous. He concentrated on selective breeding of {Southdown sheep,}and his model farm, Home farm, opposite the church, was visited by the{Duke of Sussex,}son of George III, by the{Duke of Bedford}and many farming landowners. In 1800 Southdown sheep were little known, but forty years afterwards they were bred throughout Britain. It is not surprising if Ellman is sometimes called the 'inventor' of Southdown sheep. He has left no records of how he bred his blocky compact animals from the local fine-boned leggy sheep, with light fore-quarters and speckled faces. Southdown sheep are now more widely bred abroad than in this country.
